section.para: The element align declares an ad hoc alignment of words or divs. If in a TAN-A-tok file, <align> governs <tok>s; in TAN-A-div files, <div-ref>

In TAN-A-tok files, the children are <tok>s, and <align> specifies that all the tokens invoked for one source collectively align with the tokens in the other. This version of <align> allows @cert, @bitext-relation, and @reuse-type, in addition to the editorial stamp.

In TAN-A-div files, the children are <div-ref>s, and <align> by default specifies that every <div-ref>, taken as a group, is to be aligned with every other <div-ref>. This version of <align> allows @strength, @exclusive, and @distribute, which affect the default behavior of <align> (see documentation on specific attributes for details).

Definition: (@include | ([[ {TAN-A-div.rng:} (@xml:id | (@strength?, @exclusive?, @distribute?)) OR {TAN-A-tok.rng:} (@xml:id?, @bitext-relation?, @reuse-type?)]], [[ {TAN-A-div.rng:} (@ed-who, @ed-when)? OR {TAN-class-2.rng:} (@cert?, (@ed-who, @ed-when)?)]], (<comment>* & [[ {TAN-A-div.rng:} (@alignments | <div-ref>+) OR {TAN-A-tok.rng:} <tok>+]])))
Used by:

listitem.para: @distribute has no effect on an align that invokes only one work
@distribute requires one-to-one correlation between each atomic ref in each work / source

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring02"> <body bitext-relation="B-descends-from-A" reuse-type="adaptation" in-progress="false"> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="2"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="3"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="3"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="4"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="4"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="5"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="5"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="A"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="A"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="pocket"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="pocket"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="full"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="full"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="of"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="of"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="posies"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="posies"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 3" ord="1, 2"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 3" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 3" ord="3 - 4"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 3" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="1"/> </align> <align> ........... </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="3"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="last-1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="last-1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="last"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="last"/> </align> </body> </TAN-A-tok>

section.para: The element implicit-div-type-refs indicates that div types will be dropped for one or more sources, so that references to <div>s in that source will be exclusively through @n values.
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (@include | |@src)
Used by:

listitem.para: Implicitation not allowed for sources with empty values for @n.
Implicitation not allowed for sources where ignoring types would result in duplicate flattened references to leaf divs, a violation of the Leaf Div Uniqueness Rule.

example.programlisting: <declarations> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng-uk eng-us ger eng-1790"/> <tokenization src="eng-us" which="general-1"/> </declarations>

<declarations> ........... <reuse-type xml:id="correlationGeneral"> ........... </reuse-type> <tokenization src="eng ger" which="general-1"/> <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> <rename old="e" new="4"/> </rename-div-ns> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng ger"/> </declarations>

section.para: The element rename indicates the name of a <div> @n or @type that should be changed, and the name to which it should be changed.
Definition: @old, @new
Used by:

listitem.para: Old values may not be duplicated
New values may not be duplicated
You may not change a name into one that is already in use by the source as a div-type id.
For rename-div-types, every div type must be found in every source.
For rename-div-ns, every n value must be found in at least one div type in every source.

For rename-div-ns, if a numeration system is to be renamed, the appropriate rename element must have the valid pattern identifiers in @old and @new for letter, Roman, or Arabic numerals -- #a, #i, or #1 respectively
@old and @new may not take the same value
If converting @n numeration from letter numerals to Arabic, the @n values for each div type of each source must be predominantly letter numerals
If converting @n numeration from roman numerals to Arabic, the @n values for each div type of each source must be predominantly Roman numerals

example.programlisting: <declarations> ........... <reuse-type xml:id="correlationGeneral"> ........... </reuse-type> <tokenization src="eng ger" which="general-1"/> <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> <rename old="e" new="4"/> </rename-div-ns> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng ger"/> </declarations>

section.para: The element rename-div-ns reassigns n values for one or more sources and one or more div types.

This element is especially useful for converting Roman numerals or letter numerals into Arabic numerals. This feature is strictly speaking a convenience, not a necessity. All TAN-compliant preprocessors are required to automatically detect Roman and alphabetic numbering systems and treat them as Arabic numerals.

It is also useful for div types that use descriptive names for @n (such as books of the Bible), particularly for reconciling those names with a system that prevails or is preferred (e.g., "mt" to "Matt").

Note for TAN-A-div users: Although this element can reconcile simple differences, it should not be used for more complex inconsistencies that affect alignment, best handled in the <body> of a TAN-A-div file.
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (@include | (@src, , <rename>+))
Used by:

listitem.para: Every div type value must valid in every source.
May not refer to a div type by a name that has been changed elsewhere.
For rename-div-ns, every n value must be found in at least one div type in every source.

For rename-div-ns, if a numeration system is to be renamed, the appropriate rename element must have the valid pattern identifiers in @old and @new for letter, Roman, or Arabic numerals -- #a, #i, or #1 respectively
@old and @new may not take the same value
If converting @n numeration from letter numerals to Arabic, the @n values for each div type of each source must be predominantly letter numerals
If converting @n numeration from roman numerals to Arabic, the @n values for each div type of each source must be predominantly Roman numerals

example.programlisting: <declarations> ........... <tokenization src="eng ger" which="general-1"/> <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> <rename old="e" new="4"/> </rename-div-ns> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng ger"/> </declarations>

section.para: The element rename-div-types reassigns the name of a div-type in one or more sources. This feature is strictly speaking a convenience. It does not change the underlying definiton of the div-type.
Note for TAN-A-div users: If you wish to change the underlying meaning of the div type, you should use the element <equate-div-types>
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (@include | (@src, <rename>+))
Used by:

listitem.para: Renaming div types for a source where div type references are declared to be implicit has no effect.
For rename-div-types, every div type must be found in every source.

section.para: The element suppress-div-types marks div types in a source that should be suppressed in references. Any suppression of a div type must preserve the Leaf Div Uniqueness Rule (LDUR).
This element will be used seldomly, for cases where a source has a div type that is dispensable in text references.
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (@include | (@src, ))
Used by:
The element tok identifies one or more words or word fragments, to make assertions.
Definition: [[ {TAN-A-div.rng:} (@ed-who, @ed-when)? OR {TAN-class-2.rng:} (@cert?, (@ed-who, @ed-when)?)]], @src, @ref, @val?, @ord?, @chars?
Used by:

listitem.para: May not be used to split a leaf div more than once in the same place.
Requires a tokenization declaration.
May not point to the same token that a sibling tok element does.
Must point to a string value via @val, a sequence via @ord, or both.
Every value of @ref must be found in every source.
Every token picked must appear in every ref in every source
If @chars is used, every character must appear in every token in every ref in every source
@ref must refer to a leaf div in every source
Sources that take implicit div type references may not be mixed with those that take explicit ones.
May not be used to split a leaf div at the first token.
If you insert a question mark anywhere as the value of @ord and then validate the file, you will be given a list of allowed values.
If you insert a question mark anywhere as the value of @chars and then validate the file, you will be given a list of allowed values.
If you insert a question mark anywhere as the value of @val and then validate the file, you will be given a list of allowed values.

example.programlisting: <TAN-A-tok TAN-version="1" id="tag:parkj@textalign.net,2015:TAN-A-tok,ring01+ring02"> <head> <declarations> ........... <reuse-type xml:id="adaptation"> ........... </reuse-type> <tokenization src="ring1881 ring1987" which="general-1"/> </declarations> </head> <body bitext-relation="B-descends-from-A" reuse-type="adaptation" in-progress="false"> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="2"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="3"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="3"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="4"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="4"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 1" ord="5"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 1" ord="5"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="A"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="A"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="pocket"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="pocket"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="full"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="full"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="of"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="of"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 2" val="posies"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 2" val="posies"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 3" ord="1, 2"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 3" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 3" ord="3 - 4"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 3" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="3"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="2"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="last-1"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="last-1"/> </align> <align> <tok src="ring1881" ref="line 4" ord="last"/> <tok src="ring1987" ref="l 4" ord="last"/> </align> </body> </TAN-A-tok>

section.para: The element tokenization specifies a tokenization method to be applied to one or more sources, either by (1) pointing to a TAN-R-tok file, (2) pointing by IDREF to a <recommended-tokenization> in a source, or (3) using a reserved tokenization keyword.
Class 2 files that do not require tokenization (i.e., TAN-A-div) must include <tokenization> only if the file uses elements (e.g., <split-leaf-div-at>) that assume tokenization.
Definition: (@ed-who, @ed-when)?, (@include | (@src, (@which | |(<IRI>, (<name>+, <desc>*), <checksum>*, <location>+))))
Used by:

listitem.para:
Common tokenization errors:
'location
fails
to
point
to
an
available
document a
required
@which
is
missing points
to
a
recommended-tokenization
element
where
the
location
element
fails
to
point
to
an
available
document @which
is
neither
in
the
source
nor
is
it
a
reserved
keyword core
TAN-R-tok
invoked but
is
somehow
unavailable tokenizations
fail
to
accommodate
every
language
used
by
a
source'

example.programlisting: <declarations> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng-uk eng-us ger eng-1790"/> <tokenization src="eng-us" which="general-1"/> </declarations>

<declarations> ........... <reuse-type xml:id="correlationGeneral"> ........... </reuse-type> <tokenization src="eng ger" which="general-1"/> <rename-div-ns src="ger" div-type-ref="Zeile"> <rename old="#a" new="#1"/> <rename old="e" new="4"/> </rename-div-ns> <implicit-div-type-refs src="eng ger"/> </declarations>
